bibl.title: Iwamatus Matsuro v. T.W. Lynch. Return
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the Matter of the Application of Iwamatus Matsuro for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
T.W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, Respondent:
To the Honorable Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington.

NOW comes the respondent, T.W. Lynch, Acting United States Commissioner of Immigration for the District of Washington, with headquarters at the port of Seattle, Washington, and for answer and return to the order to show cause issued herein requiring said respondent to show cause why the writ of habeas corpus should not be granted herein, says that he here produce the body of IWAMATUS MATSURO, the person named in the petition for said writ, in obedience to the command and direction of said order to show cause; and for further answer and return to said order avers that he is detaining in his custody the said IWAMATUS MATSURO for deportation from the United States as an alien Japanese person not entitled to admission under the laws of the United States, the said IWAMATUS MATSURO having been heretofore arrested and detained by this respondent under a warrant of arrest issued by the Secretary of Labor of the United States, and thereafter having been ordered
deported by said Secretary of Labor, said order to this respondent being in the form of a telegram from said Secretary of Labor, dated November 25, 1921, reading as follows:
DETHRONE JAPAN MAMORU NISHIKAWA MINUS LIKEN
(Dethrone being a code word, the translation of which is as follows:
Hearing having been granted, you will deport the following-named alien to the country named at the expense of the appropriation "expensesof regulating immigration".
Minus being a code word, the translation of which is as dollows:
Entered in violation of rule 11 of the immigration rules.
Liken beign a code word, the translation of which is as follows:
Likely to become a public charge at time of entry).

Respondent attaches hereto the original record, order, decision and exhibits, both on the hearing before the Immigration Inspector at Seattle, Washington, and the record of the submission of said hearing to the Secretary of Labor, which papers are hereby made a part and parcel of this return the same as if copied herein in full.
WHEREFORE, respondent prays that said writ of habeas corpus be denied.
T.W. LYNCH, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says:
That he is acting commissioner of immigration, named in the foregoing return; that he has read the said return and knows the contents thereof, and that he believes the same to be true.
SUBSCRIBED and sworn to before me this 5th day of December, 1921.
In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington
In the Matterof the Application of Iwamatsu Matsuro for writ of habeas corpus
Filed in the United States District Court
